did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: John L. Heatwole Collection 1802-1901

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John L. Heatwole Collection, Collection #2040, Special Collections, Carrier Library, James Madison University, Harrisonburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Donated to Carrier Library by John L. Heatwole of Bridgewater, Va., on several occasions beginning in December, 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of legal and business documents from Rockingham, Augusta, and Page Counties from 1802 to 1901. It also contains herbal recipes and other documents used by the donor in his 1995 book, Shenandoah Voices. The collector's theme was to acquire documents that, by virtue of the person who signed it, or the letterhead it bore, or the printer, or the location of the event, or some other characteristic, had distinct and particular significance to Shenandoah Valley history. Accompanying the collection are notes by the donor on most of the individual documents.

did.unittitle: Green Valley and Page County Documents 1802-1901
Arrest warrent for Jacob Cherryholmes for swearing "three profain oaths." 1802
Order for the seizure of goods of George Pence for non-payment of a debt. 1802
Dry River Road petition. 1807

scopecontent.p: One of the signers is Samuel Gilmore who was badly wounded by broadsword and bayonet at the Battle pf Waxhaws, South Carolina on May 29, 1780. The battle has also been called Buford's Defeat (after the American Commander) and Colonel Tarleton's Massacre (after the British Commander).

did.unittitle: Indenture of George and Joseph Hamilton and James Anderson to Samuel Henry in Rockingham County. 1808
Indenture of James Smily to John Carthrea in Rockingham County. 1808
Bond between David Thompson and Henry Smith on one part and Asher Waterman Sheriff of Rockingham County. 1809
Note of obligation "printed by Jacob D. Dietrick." Dietrick(h) was one of the first valley printers, first in Winchester, then in Staunton. 1809
Summons issued for Aaron Gains. 1809
List of Rockingham County court cases of interest to Augusta County officials. 1810

scopecontent.p: It is signed by Judge John McDowell and attorney Chapman Johnson who served in the Virginia Senate and House of Delegates and was one of the most respected lawyers in Western Virginia. He was born in Louisa County in 1779.

did.unittitle: Order for the seizure or goods of George Pants and Paul (?) for non-payment of a debt. 1811
Road Petition for "We the Naked Creek people." Eastern Rockingham County. 1811
Document signed by Justice Asher Waterman. 1812

scopecontent.p: Waterman had been a surgeon for the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War. Later he owned and sold thousands of acres of land in western Rockingham County.

did.unittitle: Estate receipt. Rockingham County. 1817
Document signed by John Crummy as a Justice of the Peace for Rockingham County. 1818

scopecontent.p: He is holding a hearing at the tavern of Thomas Lanahan to hear a complaint against a barney ward brought by another Harrisonburg tavern keeper, James Duff. Crummy was a gunsmith by trade.

did.unittitle: Virginia tax receipt. Orange County. 1827
Greenville lots tax receipts. 1834
List of 1836 tax levy showing 4645 tithables. 1836
Legal receipt of John Newton. 1841
Document signed by Wm. Robertson, a Virginia state senator in the 1840s. 1845
Document authorizing a payment to the Rockingham County jailer, Peter Irick, for repairs he has made to the jail. It is signed by Henry Gambill, the clerk of county court. 1847
Complaint filed by William Brown against Zachariah Raines. 1857

scopecontent.p: Raines was known as the Commodore of the Shenandoah River Fleet. He organized and led the flatboat flotillas down the Shenandoah River to Harper's Ferry in the early 19th century.

did.unittitle: Tax receipt signed by John Newton, Agent for C.H. McCormick of Augusta County. 1861
Notice of debt to Joseph Salyards by George Petty. 1868
Document signed by Joseph Salyards, considered by many to be the most learned man in the Valley prior to the Civil War. 1870
Documents signed by James Kerr Edmondson. 1889

scopecontent.p: He was Colonel of the 27th Virginia Infantry Regiment (Stonewall Brigade) during the Civil War. He lost his left arm on May 3, 1863 at the Battle of Chancellorsville. Later he served as Mayor of Lexington, Virginia.

did.unittitle: Business letterhead. The Harrisonburg Steam Pottery Company. 1896

scopecontent.p: The company was founded by Emanual Suter who was trained before the Civil War as a folk potter. This is in his handwriting.

did.unittitle: Business letterhead. S.H. Heatwole Eureka Roller Mills. 1896
Business letterhead. C.H. Eshman Fine Cigars, Harrisonburg, Virginia. 1897
Business letterhead. Bridgewater Manufacturing Company. 1901

scopecontent.p: This was located where Wildwood Park now stands.

did.unittitle: Zigler Documents 1828-1850

scopecontent.p: recepits for muster fines and orders granting Private Entertainment to John or David Zigler of Timberville, VA, 1828-1850. Purchased by donor at Zigler auction ca. 1989.

did.unittitle: Recipes

scopecontent.p: 2 printed and 2 handwritten recipes for herbal cures and for gunpowder, with explanatory notes by donor.
